case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh v. Deoman Upadhyaya

facts.text: Civil and Sessions Judge, Gyanpur convicted Deoman Upadhyaya of intentionally causing the death of Sukhdei in the early hours of June 19, 1958, at village Anandadih, District Varanasi

anchor.surface_text: Shah, J. The Civil and Sessions Judge, Gyanpur, companyvicted Deoman Upadhyaya - respondent to this appeal - of intentionally causing the death of one Sukhdei in the early hours of June 19, 1958, at village Anandadih, District Varanasi,

facts.text: Sessions Judge sentenced Deoman Upadhyaya to death subject to confirmation by the High Court

anchor.surface_text: and sentenced him to death subject to companyfirmation by the High Court. The order of companyviction and sentence was set aside by the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad.

facts.text: High Court set aside conviction and sentence and acquitted Deoman Upadhyaya

anchor.surface_text: The order of companyviction and sentence was set aside by the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad. Against that order of acquittal, the State of Uttar Pradesh has appealed to this companyrt with a certificate granted by the High Court.

facts.text: State of Uttar Pradesh appealed to Supreme Court against High Court acquittal with certificate

anchor.surface_text: Against that order of acquittal, the State of Uttar Pradesh has appealed to this companyrt with a certificate granted by the High Court. Deoman was married to one Dulari.

facts.text: Deoman was married to Dulari

anchor.surface_text: Deoman was married to one Dulari. Dularis parents had died in her infancy and she was brought up by Sukhdei, her companysin.

facts.text: Dulari brought up by Sukhdei, her cousin

anchor.surface_text: Dularis parents had died in her infancy and she was brought up by Sukhdei, her companysin. Sukhdei gifted certain agricultural lands inherited by her from her father to Dulari.

facts.text: Sukhdei gifted agricultural lands to Dulari

anchor.surface_text: Sukhdei gifted certain agricultural lands inherited by her from her father to Dulari. The lands gifted to Dulari and the lands of Sukhdei were cultivated by Mahabir, uncle of Deoman.

facts.text: Lands cultivated by Mahabir, uncle of Deoman

anchor.surface_text: The lands gifted to Dulari and the lands of Sukhdei were cultivated by Mahabir, uncle of Deoman. Mahabir and Deoman entered into negotiations for the sale of some of these lands situated at village Anandadih,

facts.text: Mahabir and Deoman negotiated sale of lands at Anandadih, Sukhdei refused

anchor.surface_text: Mahabir and Deoman entered into negotiations for the sale of some of these lands situated at village Anandadih, but Sukhdei refused to agree to the proposed sale. According to the case of the prosecution,

facts.text: Evening of June 18, 1958, altercation between Deoman and Sukhdei

anchor.surface_text: According to the case of the prosecution, in the evening of June 18, 1958, there was an altercation between Deoman and Sukhdei. Deoman slapped Sukhdei on her face and threatened that he would smash her face.

facts.text: Deoman slapped Sukhdei and threatened to smash her face

anchor.surface_text: Deoman slapped Sukhdei on her face and threatened that he would smash her face. Early in the morning of June 19, Deoman made a murderous assault with a gandasa  which was borrowed by him from one Mahesh  upon Sukhdei

facts.text: Early morning June 19, 1958, Deoman assaulted Sukhdei with gandasa borrowed from Mahesh, killed her in courtyard

anchor.surface_text: Early in the morning of June 19, Deoman made a murderous assault with a gandasa  which was borrowed by him from one Mahesh  upon Sukhdei who was sleeping in the companyrtyard near her house and killed her on the spot and thereafter,

facts.text: Deoman threw gandasa into village tank, washed himself, absconded

anchor.surface_text: he threw the gandasa into the village tank, washed himself and absconded from the village. He was arrested in the afternoon of the 20th near the village Manapur.

facts.text: Deoman arrested afternoon of June 20, 1958 near village Manapur

anchor.surface_text: He was arrested in the afternoon of the 20th near the village Manapur. On June 21, he offered to hand over the gandasa which he said, he had thrown in the village tank,

facts.text: June 21, 1958, Deoman offered to hand over gandasa from tank, recovered in presence of IO and witnesses, stained with human blood

anchor.surface_text: On June 21, he offered to hand over the gandasa which he said, he had thrown in the village tank, and in the presence of the investigating officer and certain witnesses, he waded into the tank and took out a gandasa, which, on examination by the Serologist, was found to be stained with human blood.

facts.text: Sessions Judge held altercation, slap, threat on June 18 proved

anchor.surface_text: The trial Judge, on a companysideration of the evidence led by the prosecution, held the following facts proved - In the evening of June 18, 1958, there was an altercation between Sukhdei and Deoman over the proposed transfer of lands in village Anandadih and in the companyrse of the altercation,

facts.text: Sessions Judge held Deoman borrowed gandasa from Mahesh evening June 18

anchor.surface_text: In the evening of June 18, 1958, Deoman borrowed a gandasa  Ex. 1  from one Mahesh. Before day-break on June 19, 1958, Deoman was seen by a witness for the prosecution hurrying towards the tank

facts.text: Sessions Judge held Deoman seen hurrying to tank and bathing before daybreak June 19, absconded

anchor.surface_text: Before day-break on June 19, 1958, Deoman was seen by a witness for the prosecution hurrying towards the tank and shortly thereafter he was seen by another witness taking his bath in the tank. Deoman absconded immediately thereafter

facts.text: Sessions Judge held recovery of blood-stained gandasa at Deoman's instance on June 21 proved

anchor.surface_text: That on June 21, 1958, Deoman, in the presence of the investigating officer and two witnesses, offered to hand over the gandasa which he said he had thrown into a tank, and thereafter he led the officer and the witnesses to the tank at Anandadih and in their presence waded into the tank and fetched the gandasa  Ex. 1  out of the water.

facts.text: Sessions Judge concluded Deoman committed murder of Sukhdei early morning June 19, 1958

anchor.surface_text: This gandasa was found by the Chemical Examiner and Serologist to be stained with human blood. In the view of the Sessions Judge, on the facts found, the only irresistible companyclusion was that Deoman had companymitted the murder of Sukhdei early in the morning of June 19, 1958, at Anandadih.

facts.text: High Court Division Bench referred questions on validity of s.27 Evidence Act and s.162(2) CrPC to Full Bench

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of the reference made by the companyrt of Session for companyfirmation of sentence and the appeal filed by Deoman before the High Court at Allahabad, it was companytended that the evidence that Deoman made a statement before the police and two witnesses on June 21, 1958,...

facts.text: Full Bench: Mukherjee and Srivastava JJ held s.27 void under Art.14, Desai J negative

anchor.surface_text: The reference was heard by M. C. Desai, B. Mukherjee and A. P. Srivastava, JJ. Mukherjee, J., and Srivastava, J., opined on the first question, that s. 27 of the Indian Evidence Act creates an unjustifiable discrimination...

facts.text: Another Division Bench excluded Deoman's statement under s.27, rejected borrowing of gandasa, accepted other facts but acquitted for insufficient evidence

anchor.surface_text: In the light of the opinion of the Full Bench, the learned Judges excluded from companysideration the statement made by Deoman in the presence of the police officer and the witnesses offering to point out the gandasa... They held that the story that Deoman had borrowed a gandasa... was unreliable.

facts.text: Supreme Court held s.27 valid, not violative of Art.14

anchor.surface_text: In that view, the High Court was in error in holding that s. 27 of the Indian Evidence Act and s. 162, sub-s.  2 , of the Code of Criminal Procedure in so far as that section relates to s. 27 of the Indian Evidence Act are void as offending Art. 14 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Supreme Court reviewed evidence, restored conviction and confirmed death sentence

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly set aside the order passed by the High Court and restore the order passed by the Court of Session. ... We accordingly companyfirm the sentence of death.

anchor.surface_text: Section 27 which is in form of a proviso states Provided that, when any fact is deposed to as discovered in consequence of information received from a person accused of any offence, in the custody of a police officer,

arguments.claim: Persons not in custody deemed to surrender by giving information

anchor.surface_text: Section 46 of the Code of Criminal Procedure does not contemplate any formality before a person can be said to be taken in custody submission to the custody by word or action by a person is sufficient.

holdings.text: Section 27 of the Indian Evidence Act and sub-section (2) of Section 162 of the Code of Criminal Procedure insofar as it relates to Section 27 of the Indian Evidence Act are not void as offending Article 14 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: In that view, the High Court was in error in holding that s. 27 of the Indian Evidence Act and s. 162, sub-s. ( 2 , of the Code of Criminal Procedure in so far as that section relates to s. 27 of the Indian Evidence Act are void as offending Art. 14 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Classification distinguishing persons in police custody from those not in custody for admissibility of discovery-based information is reasonable, based on intelligible differentia with nexus to legislative object of protecting against coercion while enabling truth discovery; presumption of constitutionality applies; supported by US precedents on practical classification.

holdings.text: Sub-section (2) of Section 162 of the Code of Criminal Procedure insofar as it relates to Section 27 of the Indian Evidence Act is not void under Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: In that view, the High Court was in error in holding that s. 27 of the Indian Evidence Act and s. 162, sub-s. ( 2 , of the Code of Criminal Procedure in so far as that section relates to s. 27 of the Indian Evidence Act are void as offending Art. 14 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso in s.162(2) saves operation of s.27; no independent violation as tied to valid s.27; harmonious construction with Evidence Act provisions.

holdings.text: The distinction under Section 27 between statements by persons in custody and not in custody does not deprive persons in custody of equality before the law or equal protection under Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: It is provable if he was in custody at the time when he made it, otherwise it is not. Are persons in custody, by this distinction deprived of equality before the law, or the equal protection of the laws within the meaning of Art. 14 of the Constitution ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Persons in custody require greater protection from tainted evidence due to vulnerability; non-custody persons deemed to submit to custody by voluntarily giving information (per s.46 CrPC); practical realities justify; not arbitrary.

holdings.text: The expression 'accused of any offence' in Section 27 is descriptive of the person against whom evidence is led in a criminal trial and does not require formal accusation at the time the information is given.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the defence contended that in any event Deoman was not at the time when he made the statement, attributed to him, accused of any offence and on that account also apart from the constitutional plea the statement was not provable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consistent with interpretation in Pakala Narayan Swamy v. Emperor; adjectival clause describes trial context, not precondition at statement time; applies to pre-investigation statements.

holdings.text: So much of the information given by Deoman on June 21, 1958, as relates distinctly to the discovery of the gandasa (his statement that he had thrown it in the tank) is admissible under Section 27.

anchor.surface_text: Section 27 which is in form of a proviso states Provided that, when any fact is deposed to as discovered in consequence of information received from a person accused of any offence, in the custody of a police officer,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fact discovered (gandasa location and recovery) consequent to information; only portion distinctly relating (that he threw it there) provable; bloodstains confirm link; Deoman in custody post-arrest.

holdings.text: Deoman Upadhyaya is guilty of the murder of Sukhdei under Section 302 IPC; conviction restored.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence, it is true, is purely circumstantial but the facts proved establish a chain which is consistent only with his guilt and not with his innocence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Complete chain of circumstances: altercation and threat evening prior (proved), seen hurrying to tank and bathing pre-dawn, absconded, produced bloodstained gandasa saying he threw it there; motive from land sale dispute; Sessions Judge findings accepted barring unreliable borrowing evidence.

holdings.text: The sentence of death imposed by the Sessions Judge is confirmed.

anchor.surface_text: Having carefully considered the circumstances in which the offence is proved to have been committed, we do not think that any case is made out for not restoring the order imposing the death sentence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Brutal, premeditated murder of defenceless elderly benefactress with sharp weapon over property dispute; no mitigating factors; powers under Art.136 to confirm as High Court did not.

anchor.surface_text: Having carefully considered the circumstances in which the offence is proved to have been committed, we do not think that any case is made out for not restoring the order imposing the death sentence. We accordingly set aside the order passed by the High Court and restore the order passed by the Court of Session.

outcome.relief_summary: Set aside High Court acquittal order, restored Sessions Court conviction for murder and death sentence, confirmed the death sentence under Article 136.
directions: Sentence of death cannot be executed unless confirmed by High Court, but confirmed by Supreme Court
